The first idealizers of the principle that today has become artificial intelligence are Allen Newell and Herbert Simon. They created a computer problem, called the “General Problem Solver”, which, as the name suggests, was intended to solve all universal problems that were inputted to the machine.  It was able to solve some simple problems, like the Tower of Hanoi, but, when it came to more real world, and therefore more complex, challenges, it was not able to solve them, because of the “Combinatorial Explosion”. This is a famous term in artificial intelligence studies. It can be described as the enormous amount of possibilities, data, and information that you may have to make a decision, thus, making the problem intractable. This group of people idealized the General Problem Solver with the Symbolic Systems approach. What do I mean? It is not that the GPS (not global positioning system haha) can be considered real artificial intelligence as we imagine in our minds with machines learning new concepts, having experiences, intuitions, and emotions. Symbolic systems are based on the matching patterns of symbols. Example in a medical context: If a patient is coughing, then check the temperature. If the temperature is more than X degrees Fahrenheit, then this patient has bronchitis.  They believed that symbols and pattern matching were the key to general intelligence. Maybe it is.
